Barrier - Protecting your House and Family

( words)

Introduction

This project was set to give my classmates and I some hands on experience building electromechanical products and understanding the coding and componentry needed to make these products function. We had to design and build an intruder alarm that is functional while not being an eyesore.

Barrier is the intruder alarm I designed. It is a wall mounted, ultrasonic range detector with user friendly functionality. It is easy to install and maintain. If someone breaks the ultrasonic rangers 10cm range an alarm goes off if the room is dark. A pin code is neeeded to turn the alarm off.

The project was split into 2 sections Part A and Part B. Part A involved designing the exterior and the internals and Part B involved writing the code using Arduino to get it to work.

Part A

Discover

Designing for injection moulding is a very exact process. This is because of the pitfalls in the materials and the process itself.

The average wall thickness of an injection moulded piece is between 2-4mm but injection moulding can produce walls as thin as 0.5mm but these are inclined to bend and snap. Stress builds up in these areas and can crack or snap the material. A wall too thick is almost certain to morph because the walls cool faster than the centre and the material closes in on itself.

Uniform wall thickness is also important. This is to avoid residual stress as well as sinking, warping and improve mould cycle times. A gradual change is important if changing wall thickness so that stress is reduced.

The inside corner radii should be at least the same dimension as the material thickness. Radii both improve material flow through a mould and reduces the stress that occurs at sharp corners which can lead to cracks and bending.

Undercuts occur when side action is needed to remove a piece from a mould. This is not wanted and should be avoided. Normally a simple redesign of the mould shape will solve this problem.

Snap features are an economical method of fastening as moulded into part. The down side is the risk of fatigue due to high stress and strain levels. These are used in most products and can be very important to an objects integrity.

Ideation

It was requested we don't spend a lot of time focusing on the exterior shape of the object as the interiors and other details were of more importance for this project. Therefore basic forms were sketched first to get a rough idea of where I was going.

After drawing basic forms I moved onto drawing details onto these shapes so that A shape was completed.

Concept Development

After deciding on a final form it was important to make sure the design details worked out. This intruder alarm uses an ultrasonic ranger to set off an alarm that can be disabled using the pin code.

Designing the Internals

As with all electronical based projects the internals of the product are as important as the externals. The internals for this project included a circuit board. a battery, buttons and a LED.

Revising the form of the alarm because of the internals is another important part of the design process.

The internals of the separate ultrasonic ranger were designed in conjunction with the base station.

After Editing the size of the base station it was thought the buzzer and light sensor would work better in this external part.

To fit the covers to the parts, snap features are needed these come in several designs. It is also important to avoid undercuts while designing for these.

Final Design

Sketching a product in a exploded view can show a quick overview of all the parts in the assembly.

Part B

Designers increasingly have to develop hacking and coding skills in order to keep at the leading edge of NPD (New product Development). Open source hardware and software allows us flexibility to build prototype devices to test our creative solutions in the real world. SEEED studio components and Arduino equipment provides designers with the basic building blocks to realise these solutions. This project element is designed to give you some hands on practical experience of building electro mechanical product and understanding the coding and componentry needed to make these products function.

Discover

What is an Arduino?

An Arduino is for an open source project for building digital devices. They are developed by a number of different companies and all are single board micro controllers.

The Arduino board I was using was an Arduino UNO with a Seeeduino shield on top of it. This allowed for the easy assembly and disassembly of the products. The Seeding shield is used mostly for prototyping before the board gets soldered together in an actual assembly.

What Parts are Available?

  • 1*Base Shield
  • 1*Grove - LCD RGB Backlight
  • 1*Grove - Smart Relay
  • 1*Grove - Buzzer
  • 1*Grove - Sound Sensor
  • 1*Grove - Touch Sensor
  • 1*Grove - Rotary Angle Sensor
  • 1*Grove - Temperature Sensor
  • 1*Grove - LED
  • 1*Grove - Light Sensor
  • 1*Grove â€“ Button
  • 1*DIP LED Blue-Blue
  • 1*DIP LED Green-Green
  • 1*DIP LED Red-Red
  • 1*Mini Servo
  • 10*Grove Cables
  • 1*9V to Barrel Jack Adapter
  • 1*Ultrasonic Ranger
  • 1*PIR motion sensor

Iterations

Iterating the code until the Arduino acted as desired was an important part of the process. I videoed every step of the way to show the difference.

The above video shows the buzzer going off once the ultrasonic range is broken. The range is set at 2cm. 

			
					#include "Ultrasonic.h"
					Ultrasonic sonic(5); // Start Ultrasonic Ranger
					const int buzzer = 3; // Find Buzzer
					void setup() {
    				pinMode(buzzer, OUTPUT); // Buzzer Initialised
					}
					void loop() {
  					long RangeInCentimeters; // Name the Range Number

						RangeInCentimeters = sonic.MeasureInCentimeters(); // Get the Range
						if(RangeInCentimeters < 2) { // If Range is broken from 2cm
  						digitalWrite(buzzer, HIGH); // Set Off Buzzer
  						delay(150); // Wait 150ms
  						digitalWrite(buzzer,LOW); // Turn Off Buzzer
						} else {
  						digitalWrite(led,LOW); // Turn Off Buzzer
						}
					}

The above video shows the buzzer or LED in this case not going off if the alarm isn't set. It is set by a press of a button. 

			
					#include "Ultrasonic.h"
					Ultrasonic sonic(5);
					const int led = 3;
					const int touch = 9;
					void setup() {
    					pinMode(led, OUTPUT);
    					pinMode(touch, INPUT);
					}
					void loop() {
  						long RangeInCentimeters;
  						int sensorValue = digitalRead(touch);
        				RangeInCentimeters = sonic.MeasureInCentimeters();
      					if(sensorValue == HIGH) {
       					// touch sensor is pressed ultrasonic ranger wonâ€™t
       					// turn on light
        					if(RangeInCentimeters < 2) {
          						digitalWrite(led, HIGH);
          						delay(150);
          						digitalWrite(led,LOW);
							} else {
          						digitalWrite(led,LOW);
        					}
						}
					}

Testing the threshold of the light sensor.

A final working prototype was created. When placed inside an entrance, alarm will go off once door is open. 

			
void loop() {
  long RangeInCentimeters; // Range Long
  int sensorValue = analogRead(0); // Light Sensor init
  buttonState = digitalRead(button); // Read Button State
  touchState = digitalRead(touch); // Read Touch State
  RangeInCentimeters = sonic.MeasureInCentimeters(); // Find how far object is
        if(sensorValue 	< thresholdvalue && RangeInCentimeters	< 10) { // Light Sensor is above threshold
         LightOn = true; // Light should be on
 }
if(LightOn) { // If LightOn = True
     digitalWrite(led, HIGH); // Turn on LED
     delay(1000); // wait a second
     digitalWrite(led, LOW); // Turn off LED
     delay(1000); // wait a second
 } else { // if LightOn = false
   digitalWrite(led, LOW); // Turn Off LED
 }
if(buttonState == 1 && touchState == HIGH) { // If Button and touch has been pressed
        LightOn = false; // LightOn is off
     }

Loop for final project hand in. Ultrasonic Ranger sets off buzzer if light sensor senses it is dark. Button and touch sensor need to be pressed to stop buzzer.
